title: The Best Way To Eat Healthy When You're Short On Time
summary: Many people assume that leftovers are unhealthy, but that’s not the case if you make smart choices. Rotating your vegetables will help you avoid falling into a pattern where you’re only eating one or two types of vegetables every week. Eating smaller meals throughout the day has been shown to increase feelings of fullness and prevent overeating at meals. Eating beans and Lentils are two of the healthiest protein sources you can eat, and you can use them to replace meat in tacos and burritos.

content.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"Plan Your Meals Ahead of Time"),mdx("p",null,`One of the biggest ways to make sure that you\u2019re eating right is to plan your meals ahead of time. It\u2019s easier to make healthy choices when you know what\u2019s coming up instead of reacting to whatever happens to be in the fridge. It\u2019s also helpful to decide what you\u2019re going to eat before you enter the kitchen. Sometimes the mere act of opening the fridge can make it harder to stick to your healthy eating plan.
Most people make healthy meal plans on paper, but you can also use an online diet app like MyFitnessPal to streamline the process.`),mdx("h2",null,"Don\u2019t Fear Leftovers"),mdx("p",null,"Many people assume that leftovers are unhealthy, but that\u2019s not the case if you make smart choices. Many foods can actually taste even better when they\u2019re reheated, which is helpful if you don\u2019t have the time or energy to cook a brand new meal."),mdx("p",null,"If you\u2019re eating leftover veggies, be sure to reheat them long enough to kill any bacteria that might have grown while the food was sitting in the fridge. Foods like pasta, rice, and potatoes can all be re-heated in a microwave, but other items may require a stovetop re-heat."),mdx("p",null,"Many experts recommend eating leftover foods as a way to lower the cost of your diet, but be sure to make healthy choices when you\u2019re re-heating. Avoid things like fried foods, fatty sauces, and heavy gravies that weren\u2019t healthy to begin with."),mdx("h2",null,"Rotate Your Veggies"),mdx("p",null,`Not all vegetables are created equally. While some are high in fiber and low in calories, others are heavy and rich in calories. It\u2019s not uncommon to see people falling into a rut where they eat the same vegetables every week. That\u2019s fine if you\u2019re eating healthy options, but it\u2019s very easy to gradually slip into a pattern where you\u2019re only eating root vegetables. Root vegetables are important, but they shouldn\u2019t be the only vegetables in your diet.
For example, you might want to include peppers in your diet once a week. Or, if you enjoy cabbages, you could make a point of eating it at least a couple times a month. Rotating your vegetables will help you avoid getting bored with your meals. It\u2019ll also help you avoid falling into a pattern where you\u2019re only eating one or two types of vegetables.`),mdx("h2",null,"Go For High-Fiber Vegetables"),mdx("p",null,`Fiber is important for healthy digestion and blood sugar balance, but some vegetables have much more of it than others. In fact, some veggies have no fiber at all, so it\u2019s important to choose wisely.
Vegetables like kale and broccoli are great sources of fiber, but you\u2019ll find fewer of these nutrients in lettuce and avocado. It\u2019s best to focus on eating plenty of veggies like kale and collard greens, as well as whole grains like oats and barley.
Vegetables and grains are two of the easiest ways to boost your daily fiber intake. It\u2019s also helpful to avoid eating too many whole grains, as they can be rich in calories.`),mdx("h2",null,"Try Beans and Lentils"),mdx("p",null,`Some people avoid eating beans and legumes because they aren\u2019t sure how to prepare them. But they happen to be two of the healthiest foods you can eat. In fact, beans have been shown to have just as many health benefits as other protein sources.
You can try eating beans in a variety of different ways, including eating them in bean burritos, salads, and in chili. Lentils are another high-protein food that can be used in a number of different dishes. You can try them in soups or stews, or you can use them to replace meat in tacos and burritos.`),mdx("h2",null,"Keep Healthy Snacks Handy"),mdx("p",null,`Keep a variety of healthy snacks handy so that you can avoid overeating at meals. It\u2019s important to eat throughout the day, but it\u2019s also easy to overeat when you\u2019re eating more meals.
For example, if you eat three meals a day and each meal includes a baked potato, you\u2019ll be getting far more carbs than you need in one day. It\u2019s important to avoid that by keeping healthy snacks nearby so that you can eat just enough to avoid feeling hungry.
You can also try eating smaller meals more frequently throughout the day. Eating more often has been shown to increase feelings of fullness and prevent overeating at one sitting.`),mdx("h2",null,"Don\u2019t Be Afraid Of The Fridge"),mdx("p",null,`Some people are under the impression that eating vegetables out of the fridge is bad for you. While it\u2019s true that vegetables lose some of their nutritional value when they\u2019re kept in the fridge, they\u2019re still very healthy.
You can help keep vegetables fresh by cutting them up and placing them in a plastic container with a lid. You can also buy vegetables that have been pre-cut, which makes it easier to use them in a meal.
It\u2019s important to remember that eating fresh food is always better than eating something that\u2019s been sitting in your fridge for a long time.`),mdx("h2",null,"Try A Smaller Plate"),mdx("p",null,`Eating off a smaller plate is one way to trick yourself into eating less food. It\u2019s an old trick, but it works: Studies have found that people tend to eat less when they eat off smaller plates.
If you don\u2019t want to buy a new set of dishes, you can still eat off a smaller plate. Just put a folded cloth or paper towel in the center of your plate. It should be about one-third the size of your normal plate. This extra space will help you eat less without really noticing the difference.`),mdx("h2",null,"Bottom line"),mdx("p",null,"Now that you know how to eat healthy on the go, there\u2019s no excuse to fall short on your diet. Nobody has the time to spend hours in the kitchen cooking elaborate meals, but it\u2019s not hard to grab a quick snack or salad while you\u2019re out and about."),mdx("p",null,"We all lead busy lives with lots of obligations outside of work or school: we have friends, family members, and partners that we need to spend time with on a regular basis. It doesn\u2019t leave much room for eating right. Fortunately, there are lots of ways to keep your diet in check while also fitting in your hectic schedule."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Make Healthy Eating Easier with Batch Cooking
10 Ways to Make Your Commute Less Stressful

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`When you think about your daily commute, it probably doesn\u2019t strike you as being particularly stressful. In fact, many people see their daily drive to work or school as a time for peace and quiet. After all, what could possibly be stressful about getting from point A to point B?
It\u2019s true that your commute isn\u2019t inherently stressful. In theory, it\u2019s just a short period of time each day when you go from home to work (or vise versa). But even the most seemingly insignificant details can make a big difference. Read on to learn more about how you can reduce stress during your commute and get to work happier every day!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 10 Easy Ways to Cut Sugar from Your Diet

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In recent years, sugar has received a lot of negative attention. From the link between sugar and obesity to the prevalence of diabetes, research on sugar and its potential health effects continues to grow.
There are many different types of sugars out there, but common table sugar or sucrose is the one you need to cut back on. Eating too much sugar can lead to weight gain, high blood pressure and other health problems. If you\u2019ve read any articles about how bad sugar is for you, then you probably already know this. However, cutting back on sugar isn\u2019t always easy. Sugar is in almost everything! Luckily, we\u2019ve compiled a list of 10 super helpful tips that will teach you how to cut back on your intake of this not-so-nice white substance\u2026`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Make Healthy Snacks More Exciting
How to Stick to Your Healthy Eating Goals

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`The New Year brings new resolutions and the challenge to stick to them. But how can you make sure you succeed this time? Planning and preparation are key to any endeavor, including sticking to your healthy eating goals in the New Year. Thinking ahead and making a plan will help you avoid pitfalls and stay on track. After all, it\u2019s not about failing once but rather keeping failure at bay so it doesn\u2019t creep up again next year.
Many people struggle with their eating habits because they lack structure or fail to plan ahead. That\u2019s why creating a strategy is essential if you want to maintain this commitment for good. Whether it\u2019s going on a diet, cutting out certain foods or reducing your intake of fats, proteins or carbs \u2013 there are different ways how you can achieve your goals. Here are some helpful tips:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 10 Tips for Keeping Your Hair Healthy and Strong

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Keeping your hair healthy can be a challenge at times, but it's important to keep on top of things in order to prevent any further damage. Whether you have fine and sensitive locks or thick and curly tresses, the right routine will help keep your hair strong and prevent it from breaking under pressure. Keeping your hair strong is an ongoing process, but by adopting some simple tips you can make things much easier on your locks long term.
Learn how to avoid over-washing, what products are best for stronger hair, as well as what you should be doing if you see strands falling out more than normal. The latter might seem strange, but trust us: sooner rather than later that excess hair loss could indicate something more serious happening beneath the surface. Here are 10 ways to keep your hair healthy and strong...`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Best Healthy Snacks to Keep You Going

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:o,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:o,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Think about your typical work day. You probably spend the first few hours of it at your desk, sipping on a cup of coffee, reading emails, and maybe even taking a brief walk around the office to stretch your legs. Then you head back to your desk, only to dive into an afternoon filled with more reading and typing\u2014no time for walking again. And by 5pm you\u2019re ready to call it a day and head home. However, in that short span of time, you need to find some way to keep going through all those tasks. What do you do?
The answer is simple: Healthy snacks! Think about how much time you spend away from home throughout the day \u2013 whether it\u2019s at work or school, there are plenty of opportunities for snacking. In fact, keeping healthy snacks around can help boost your energy when you need it most. Check out these top-rated healthy snacks that will keep you going all day long\u2026`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Best Way to Start Your Day - With a Healthy Morning Routine

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:t,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In a world that moves as fast as ours, it can be easy to get caught up in the daily hustle and forget about the little things. But those little things are what make all the difference in the end. Take morning routines, for example. They may not seem like much on their own, but they have the power to make or break your day from start to finish.
With so many different morning routines out there, it can be difficult to know which one is right for you. There are those that are super long and involved, and others that are much shorter and simpler. Whether you\u2019re looking for something simple or something a little more intense, we\u2019ve got you covered with this ultimate guide on how to start your day with a healthy routine.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
